headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Brent and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome, everyone to the Weyerhaeuser Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions]. I now like to turn the call over to Den
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Brent and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome, everyone to the Weyerhaeuser Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions]. I now like to turn the call over to Denise Merle, Vice President of Human Resources and Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Brent. Good morning, everyone. And thank you for joining us today to discuss Weyerhaeuser's fourth quarter 2015 earnings. On the call with me this morning are Doyle Simons, CEO; Patty Bedient, CFO; and Beth Bob, Director of Investor Relations.
componenttext: Thank you, Brent. Good morning, everyone. And thank you for joining us today to discuss Weyerhaeuser's fourth quarter 2015 earnings. On the call with me this morning are Doyle Simons, CEO; Patty Bedient, CFO; and Beth Bob, Director of Investor Relations. This call is being webcast at www.weyerhaeuser.com. Our earnings release and presentation materials can also be found on our website. Please review the warning statements in our press release and on the presentation slides concerning the risks associated with forward-looking statements as forward-looking statements will be made during the conference call. We will discuss non-GAAP financial measures, and a reconciliation of GAAP can be found in the earnings material on our website. I will now turn the call over to Doyle Simon.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Denise and welcome, everyone. For the past 2 years, we have been relentlessly focused on making Weyerhaeuser a truly great company by pulling 3-key levers to drive value for shareholders. Portfolio, performance and capital allocation. In 2015,
componenttext:
Thank you, Denise and welcome, everyone. For the past 2 years, we have been relentlessly focused on making Weyerhaeuser a truly great company by pulling 3-key levers to drive value for shareholders. Portfolio, performance and capital allocation. In 2015, we made significant progress in each of these areas. We announced 2 transformational portfolio changes, a merger with Plum Creek, that will create the world's premier Timberland and force products company and the exploration of strategic alternatives for our Cellulose Fibers business. 
We maintained a relentless focus on improving our relative performance and delivered on our second set of annual operational excellence targets. And importantly, we delivered on our commitment to return cash to shareholders. We increased our dividend by 7% and we've repurchased nearly $520 million of common shares in 2015. Despite ongoing headwinds related to the strengthening of the U.S. dollar and global macroeconomic uncertainty we remain focused on what we can control. And for the fourth quarter, our business has once again delivered solid operating results. 
Weyerhaeuser reported fourth quarter net earnings of $59 million or $0.11 per diluted share on net sales of $1.7 billion. Excluding special items, we earned $121 million or $0.24 per share. Our primary special items for the fourth quarter was a noncash asset impairment in our new Sprint equity affiliate. Additional items, including cost for the Plum Creek merger and the closure of several distribution centers and a tax benefit from the expiration of our built-in games period. 
I will begin the discussion of our fourth quarter business results with some brief comments about the housing market. The housing market maintained positive momentum in the fourth quarter as favorable weather conditions enabled building activity to continue through December in many areas of the country. Single-family housing starts improved in the quarter and ended the year up 10% compared with 2014. Total U.S. housing starts into 2015 just over 1.1 million, an improvement of 11% compared with last year. 
For 2016, we expect steady moderate growth in the U.S. housing market. We are planning for just over 1.2 million housing starts in an increasing single-family share with improving job growth and historically low interest rates, U.S. economic fundamentals support a continuing recovery. Despite some headwinds from labor constraints and falling oil prices, builder sentiment remains extremely strong. Most of our customers tell us they are planning for 2016 growth rates in the low double-digits. 
Let me now turn to our business segment results starting with Timberlands, Charts 3 to 5. Timberlands contributed $134 million to fourth quarter earnings, an improvement of $8 million compared with the third quarter. In the West, fee harvest volumes rose seasonally as we exited the third quarter fire season and average log realizations increased due to a greater percentage each of our export sales. Each of our export markets improvement in the quarter. 
Log sales volumes to Japan increased and prices rose modestly as a solid Japanese housing market continues to drive demand. For the full year 2015, Japanese wooden housing starts grew by 3%. In China, log inventory at the ports declined throughout the fourth quarter as many suppliers curtailed shipment in response to weak third quarter pricing. Although overall Chinese market demand remain relatively flat compared with the third quarter, average realizations for our China export log increase and sales volumes grows as we reflect volumes to take advantage of opportunities created by the tighter Chinese inventory situation. 
In Western domestic markets, law of supply and demand remain balanced during the quarter. Realizations for our Western domestic logs declined slightly to a greater mix of [indiscernible] and other white wood. The flooding experience in some regions of Washington and in Oregon during December had no significant effect on our operations or infrastructure. In the South, heavy rainfall did affect harvest operations and select wood baskets. The fee harvest declined only 3% compared with third quarter as our Southern Timberlands did an outstanding job of flexing harbor settings in response to weather conditions. 
Although overall market conditions were stable, realizations for our southern logs declined slightly due to a shift in geographic mix. Silviculture and expenses declined due to cost control initiatives and weather-related constraints. Fourth quarter included earnings of $19 million from disposition and nonstrategic Timberlands, an increase of $6 million compared with the third quarter. 
Wood Products, Charts 6 and 7. Wood Products contributed $48 million to fourth quarter earnings before special items, compared with $85 million in the third quarter. Special items for the fourth quarter included a pretax charge of $8 million for the closure of 4 distribution centers as we continue to improve the cost structure of that business. Adjusted EBITDA before special items for the Wood Products segment declined to $75 million in the fourth quarter as seasonally lower sales volumes and lower operating rates more than offset improved realizations for oriented [indiscernible]. 
In lumber, EBITDA was $22 million lower compared with the third quarter. Average realizations declined 3% and sales volumes fell 9%. Operating rates declined and unit manufacture costs rose due to increased downtime, primarily for installation of capital projects that will continue to reduce costs within our southern lumber system. In OSB, EBITDA improved by $13 million, primarily due to a 14% increase in average sales realizations. This improvement was partially offset by 7% reduction in sales volume and higher unit manufacture costs due to planned maintenance downtime. 
Engineered Wood Products reported fourth quarter EBITDA of $14 million compared with $36 million in the third quarter. Operating rates declined due to downtime of a major maintenance, capital projects and seasonal holiday shutdowns. Sales volumes declined seasonably and average realizations were lower due to mix. EBITDA for the Distribution business declined compared with third quarter due to seasonably lower sales volumes. 
Cellulose Fibers, Charts 8 and 9. Cellulose fibers contributed $64 million to fourth quarter earnings before special items, compared with $79 million in the third quarter. Fourth quarter results included a noncash pretax charge of $84 million for the asset impairment in our newsprint equity affiliate. Pulp prices remained under pressure during the fourth quarter due to continued strengthening of the U.S. dollar. Average pulp realizations declined compared with the third quarter and maintenance expense increased due to additional scheduled maintenance outage dates. 
Fourth quarter included 8 days of scheduled maintenance outages compared with 4 days in the third quarter. These factors were partially offset by improved sales volumes and strong operating performance. Pulp production rose compared with the third quarter despite the increase in scheduled maintenance outage days in several of our mills set operating levels. For example, our Columbus, Mississippi mill operated at nearly 100% reliability in the quarter. 
I will now turn it over to Patty to discuss our first quarter outlook and then I'll follow-up with some specific comments on operational excellence.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Doyle, and good morning, everyone. The outlook for the first quarter is summarized on Chart 12. Now this outlook does not incorporate the merger with Plum Creek. We'll include Plum Creek results after the transaction closes. I'll begin my comments
componenttext:
Thanks, Doyle, and good morning, everyone. The outlook for the first quarter is summarized on Chart 12. Now this outlook does not incorporate the merger with Plum Creek. We'll include Plum Creek results after the transaction closes. I'll begin my comments with Timberlands. In the West, export demand from Japan is expected to remain strong and we anticipate a slight improvement in pricing. The strength of the U.S. dollar continues to dampen significant price increases. Sales volumes to Japan are expected to increase more than 5% in the quarter. Our volumes and realizations for log sales to China are anticipated to increase modestly. 
We anticipate a slight increase in Western domestic sales realizations as lumber prices are expected to improve later in the quarter. Fee harvest in the West is expected to be comparable to the fourth quarter. In the South, sales realizations are expected to decrease slightly due to mix. Sales volumes will be lower as wet weather contributes to the typical seasonal decline in fee harvest. Earnings from nonstrategic land sales are anticipated to be roughly $10 million lower than the fourth quarter. 
Overall, we expect earnings in our Timberlands segment to be comparable to the fourth quarter. In Wood Products. Lumber average sales realizations are anticipated to increase in the first quarter compared to the fourth, although prices had not improved thus far. Realizations for our other product lines as well as overall sales volumes are expected to be roughly comparable to last quarter. We expect less downtime from planned maintenance and capital projects compared to the fourth quarter. And as a result, average unit manufacture costs should decrease. Channel inventories remain low with customers generally purchasing for immediate needs. As we enter the spring building season, we do expect to see business improve. 
We anticipate that overall earnings in our Wood Products segment will be higher in the first quarter compared to the fourth, and slightly higher than the first quarter of 2015. In Cellulose Fibers, global softwood pulp inventories as of the end of the fourth quarter were at 29 days, down slightly from the 30 days at the end of the third quarter. This is at the high-end of balanced inventory level. We expect that average sales realizations and volumes for our pulp products will weaken during the first quarter due to the continued currency headwinds and the normal effect of the Chinese New Year. 
Our liquid packaging operation will begin its planned maintenance outage this quarter and as a result, we expect maintenance expense for this segment will increase significantly compared to the fourth quarter, which had fewer overall maintenance days. We anticipate that earnings in our cellulose fibers segment will be significantly lower than the fourth quarter of 2015 and roughly comparable to the first quarter of last year. 
Now I'll wrap up with some overall financial comments, and I'll refer to Chart 11 for this discussion. Cash from operations totaled $339 million in the fourth quarter, an increase of $57 million from the third quarter. Capital expenditures for the fourth quarter were $174 million, bringing our total expenditures for the full year to $483 million, well within our earlier guidance of $500 million. 
Looking ahead, to 2016, we expect total expenditures for the full year to be down slightly from 2015, subject to the outcome of the strategic review for Cellulose Fibers and the transaction with Plum Creek. At the end of the quarter, we had cash of just over $1 billion and we do not have any scheduled debt maturities in 2016. Now I'd like to update you on the status of our retirement benefit plans. 
The year end 2015 funded status of our defined benefit pension plans and postemployment retirement plans improved by approximately $400 million compared to year-end 2014. This improvement was primarily the results of the increase in discount rates. We did not make any cash contributions to the U.S. qualified pension plan in 2015, and we don't anticipate any cash contributions for that plan this year. Cash paid for all other pension and other postemployment retirement plan in 2015 was approximately $80 million. We expect spending in 2016 to be approximately $60 million. 
Chart 14 in the appendix details the pension expense by business for 2015. Total expense in 2015 was approximately $42 million and in 2016, we expect the total amount will be income of approximately $5 million. So with that, I'll turn the call back to Doyle.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Patty. I'd now like to switch gears to provide an update on our operational excellence efforts. Throughout the year, each of our businesses remain relentlessly focused on achieving their respective operational excellence targets. Achieving thes
componenttext:
Thank you, Patty. I'd now like to switch gears to provide an update on our operational excellence efforts. Throughout the year, each of our businesses remain relentlessly focused on achieving their respective operational excellence targets. Achieving these targets is not easy, they're designed to stretch the business to deliver a step change in relative performance, and that's exactly what is happening through a lot of really good work by our employees. 
Chart 13 highlights our OpEx accomplishments for 2015 and our annual targets for 2016. The Timberland business delivered $39 million of operational excellence improvement in 2015, exceeding its target of $20 million to $30 million. These results were primarily, driven by cost efficiency in 3 key areas. First, harvest in. We are continuing the implementation of centralized dispatch systems to improve the efficiency of logging and clicking contractors and replacing costly cable logging with steep slope technologies. 
Second, spending on forest roads. We're adjusting the volumes of rock related during well construction and the level of road maintenance to match expected vehicle travel patterns and local weather conditions. Finally, silvicultural costs. Data we have collected on tree stand growth patterns, enable us to custom tailor silviculture prescriptions to apply pruning and hardwood control only to acres where those activity generate an optimal financial return. 
With total OpEx improvements of $64 million since 2013, the Timberlands business has achieved the $50 million to $70 million improvement goal we established 2 years ago. However, we're not done. For 2016, we are targeting an additional $20 million to $30 million of OpEx improvements from our existing Timberlands holdings. This does not include the benefit we will get from applying our OpEx efforts to over 6 million acres of Plum Creek lands. 
The lumber business achieved $21 million of improvement in 2015, meeting its target of $20 million to $25 million. Primary drivers improvements in reliability and process efficiency, and rigorous cost management as we continue to drive down our cost net of logs. Each mill is focused on maintaining consistent throughput and improving uptime by resolving process and equipment issues that create bottlenecks for stock production. 
Capital expenditures for the lumber business increased in 2015 as we invested in low risk, high return projects to further improve the cost of our mills. These projects include auto and continued. We will capture the full benefits of several of these investments in 2016. With cumulative improvements of over $40 million since 2013, the lumber business is nearing half way on its journey to $100 million of controllable manufacturing cost reductions. 
For 2016, the business is targeting OpEx improvements of $15 million to $20 million. [indiscernible] delivered $24 million of OpEx improvement in 2015, exceeding its target of $10 million to $15 million. Results were driven by improving reliability as our mills' focused on eliminating sources of downtime and recovering efficiency from outage events. Lowering and revving costs, as we optimize recipes for multiple products and increasing our mix of higher margin products such as flooring. 
For cumulative improvements of $34 million, the OSB business is more than halfway to its 60 million goal. The business is targeting another $15 million to $20 million of OpEx improvements in 2016. For engineered Wood Products and distribution, we set specific bottom line EBITDA improvement targets for 2015 as those businesses remain focused on turnaround performance. Engineered Wood Products improved full year EBITDA by $35 million compared with 2014, significantly exceeding its $15 million to $20 million target. 
Each mill maintain a rigorous focus on reducing manufacturing costs for all products. For example, maintenance team have best practices across the mill system, increasing reliability and reducing costs. Engineered Wood Products has made substantial improvements since 2013. Over the past 2 years, this business has increased annually EBITDA by almost $70 million, proving that it has ability to perform. Our focus now is continuing to improve relative performance versus the competition. The 2016 goal for this business will not be a bottom line EBITDA target, but an OpEx improvement target of $10 million to $15 million. 
Distribution improved full year EBITDA by $8 million in 2015. The business fell short of its $20 million to $30 million improvement target as it was unable to overcome the effects of severe winter weather early in the year and lower-than-expected demand in the first half of 2015. 2015 OpEx improvements were largely attributable to improved product margin and reduction of headcount, warehouse and delivery expenses. 
Improvements made to the distribution cost structure during 2015 have created a stronger foundation for better operating performance next year. In 2016, the Distribution business is targeting bottom line EBITDA improvement of $15 million to $20 million. Cellulose Fibers. Cellulose fibers delivered operational improvement of $47 million, significantly increasing its $30 million to $35 million targets, improvements were primarily attributable to lower energy cost driven by new term in generator at our planned river mill and our water conversion at Columbus and reduced usage of key chemicals at several mills adjusted processes tied to their digesters and place plans. 
During 2016, Cellulose Fibers is targeting improvement of $40 million to $50 million. With OpEx improvements of $75 million to date, this will enable the business to exceed $100 million goal established in 2013. I'll also mention the reduction in our SG&A. Part of our commitment to operational excellence is having the right cost structure across our company. Two years ago, we committed to reduce SG&A by $75 million and achieved that run rate by the end of 2014. Last year, we told you, we had delivered on that commitment and you can see our performance in this year's results. Compared with 2013, we have reduced our SG&A by over $100 million. Success in achieving our OpEx target was a critical component of Weyerhaeuser's 2015 financial performance, enabling us to offset pricing headwinds in many of our markets. 
In Timberlands, weaker year-over-year pricing for Western logs created a headwind of over $100 million. By exceeding its operational excellence target, the Timberland business was able to overcome nearly half of that deficit. Lower year-over-year realizations of11% for lumber and 9% for OSB, created a headwind of over $250 million for Wood Products earnings. However, the salient captured nearly $100 million of operational exhibit significantly mitigating the effect of these lower prices and earnings for Wood Products declined less than $70 million on a year-over-year basis. 
Cellulose Fibers saved a headwind of over $100 million from declining pulp prices, higher-priced costs and the effect of the West Coast port slow down. The business of that nearly half of this amount through its OpEx efforts. Looking forward to 2016, our relentless focus on operational excellence remains a key component of our commitment to improve our relative performance and drive value for shareholders. I will close this morning with some brief comments on our merger with Plum Creek and the strategic review of our cellulose fibers business. 
The joint registration statement associated with our announced merger with Plum Creek was declared effective by the SEC on December 28. Both ISS and, have recommend that shareholders vote in favor of the proposal. The shareholder vote will be held on February 12 and we anticipate closing the merger in the first quarter. Our joint integration team is making excellent progress as we define staffing needs, established plan for cost synergies and position the merged company for a smooth and successful day 1. 
The review of Cellulose Fibers is proceeding well and we look forward to sharing more information with you when that review is complete. As we enter 2016, I'm excited about the opportunities in front of us. Although the first few weeks of the year have been characterized by market turbulence and global macroeconomic concerns, I'm encouraged by the positive trend in U.S. housing and the optimistic tone we are hearing from our customers. 
Our portfolio changes and operational improvements are positioning Weyerhaeuser to drive long-term value for shareholders. We will remain relentlessly focused on operational excellence and disciplined capital allocation and I look forward to sharing our continued progress with you. And now, I'd like to open up the phone for questions.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Anthony Pettinari with Citi.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Anthony Pettinari with Citi.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: In Cellulose Fibers, your average prices were down I think around 10% year-over-year, which is maybe a little bit sharper than the list price decline. Can you remind us, was there any mix issues there? Or kind of what was driving the price declines, it se
componenttext: In Cellulose Fibers, your average prices were down I think around 10% year-over-year, which is maybe a little bit sharper than the list price decline. Can you remind us, was there any mix issues there? Or kind of what was driving the price declines, it seemed a little bit sharper than what we might have expected. And then just related to Cellulose Fibers, you know you're targeting an acceleration of OpEx improvements in '16, and I was wondering if you could give a little color on what's driving that kind of year-over-year.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me start. I'll let -- I'll address your second question with OpEx, and then I'll ask Patty to address your first question. And what I would tell you on OpEx is, we're gaining a lot of traction across our businesses and specifically in Cellulose Fibers
componenttext: Let me start. I'll let -- I'll address your second question with OpEx, and then I'll ask Patty to address your first question. And what I would tell you on OpEx is, we're gaining a lot of traction across our businesses and specifically in Cellulose Fibers. What we found there through Kathy's leadership is an abundance of ideas that are percolating up from a bottom-up approach in terms of continuing to drive down our overall cost structure. But the encouraging thing about OpEx overall Anthony, that we've seen it -- it started off as a top-down effort. But as we defined winning, defined exactly what we mean by OpEx and people are incented to drive OpEx, we are having just more and more ideas bubble up in terms of the opportunity. And Cathy has a full slate of those outlined and proved in 2015, ability to execute on those and more to come in 2016. So it's across the board, lower energy, lower chemicals, better reliability, all the blocking and tackling of running a Cellulose Fibers.

componenttextpreview: Sure, Anthony. So in terms of operating rates in the fourth quarter, lumber was in the high 80s, OSB was in the low 90s, and EOP was in the low 70s. In terms of pricing for OSB, if you look at its current -- our first quarter to date, average to date is d
componenttext: Sure, Anthony. So in terms of operating rates in the fourth quarter, lumber was in the high 80s, OSB was in the low 90s, and EOP was in the low 70s. In terms of pricing for OSB, if you look at its current -- our first quarter to date, average to date is down about $7 versus the fourth quarter in terms of OSB price.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of George Staphos with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of George Staphos with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Doyle, if we can talk about operational excellence first. So you're 2 years into the program. You're more than achieving your goal. I'd have to imagine that you're getting to the proverbial fruit that's may be hanging higher on the tree. So do you need to
componenttext: Doyle, if we can talk about operational excellence first. So you're 2 years into the program. You're more than achieving your goal. I'd have to imagine that you're getting to the proverbial fruit that's may be hanging higher on the tree. So do you need to have a larger funnel to get to the goals in a year like 2015 relative to what would've been the case in 2000 -- actually 2016, relative to 2015 and 2014. And the related question, ultimately running a business is a lot easier than running numbers on a spreadsheet, if you're an analyst. So what's been so difficult about getting the OE benefits to the bottom line and distribution?

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, okay. Yes, thanks for the question, George. And on OpEx, I think you said it is exactly right, is it does get more difficult as you move forward. But as I've said in response to the earlier question, what I'm really encouraged about and why we're con
componenttext: Yes, okay. Yes, thanks for the question, George. And on OpEx, I think you said it is exactly right, is it does get more difficult as you move forward. But as I've said in response to the earlier question, what I'm really encouraged about and why we're confident we're going to be able to continue to deliver on OpEx target is because it has become a part of who we are. It is being done much more from a bottoms-up approach, George. So whereas previously, it was things that were identified at the top and kind of driven down. And now more and more of these ideas to your point, it's a larger funnel, more and more ideas are coming from our employee base, which they are -- it points out that they're doing the hard work every day when they understand what the opportunities are, recognize that they are empowered to go do something and then incented to do that is amazing what can happen. So you're right, it is a different approach. But very encouraged by the progress and most importantly, its becoming part of our culture. And that's why we're, year after year, we're going to be able to continue to drive operational excellence as we move forward. In terms of distribution. George, it's been -- while we have made, I think it's important to highlight that we have made improvement there and if you look at it, we've made $40 million plus improvement over the last few years and bottom line distribution EBITDA, but we're still not where we need to be to your point. This year, hey using weather, but weather did have an impact in the first half of the year, lower-than-expected demand and the fact that we had kind of eroding commodity prices throughout the year may be its ability to leverage margin improvements. As we said, we made some significant changes to the cost structure by closing Forsyth to reduce the print -- footprint of the cost structure and really focus on our growth markets going forward. And I'll tell you with those changes, we are confident that we're going to be able to continue to improve our Distribution business. But still a lot of work to do there and still work to do frankly, to prove that we deserve to be in this business long-term. But good progress and again, with the structural changes we made in the fourth quarter, optimistic about that business going forward.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And my last question, I'll turn it over 2-part unrelated, I guess, that's 2 questions then. First of all, what kind of pricing are you expected on average for wood sequentially versus fourth quarter to hit your guidance? And then in SG&A, you've mor
componenttext: Okay. And my last question, I'll turn it over 2-part unrelated, I guess, that's 2 questions then. First of all, what kind of pricing are you expected on average for wood sequentially versus fourth quarter to hit your guidance? And then in SG&A, you've more than achieved your target. Should we assume that SG&A is now flat on a going forward basis.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you George. In terms of pricing, as Patty outlined, we anticipate pricings in fact be higher in lumber in the first quarter versus the fourth quarter, however, that's still in front of us. If you look at it currently, quarter to date prices for lumb
componenttext: Thank you George. In terms of pricing, as Patty outlined, we anticipate pricings in fact be higher in lumber in the first quarter versus the fourth quarter, however, that's still in front of us. If you look at it currently, quarter to date prices for lumber are down approximately $7 versus the fourth quarter average. Encouraging prices were up $4, $5 this week, so we'll see where it plays out. But normally, you start to see an inflection point in lumber prices mid- to late-February as the spring season -- as billing season kicks in. And we would hope to see the same type of price inflection or improvement in OSB as we move to the quarter as well, and that's what's baked into -- generally baked into our guidance for the first quarter.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, George. As you think about wood products, the primary price increase quarter-over-quarter that we have baked into our guidance is in lumber. And I would say we're looking for something low single digits in lumber. And the OSB and engineered wood comb
componenttext: Yes, George. As you think about wood products, the primary price increase quarter-over-quarter that we have baked into our guidance is in lumber. And I would say we're looking for something low single digits in lumber. And the OSB and engineered wood combination of those 2 probably the results would, in our guidance, would be roughly flat from a pricing perspective. But as Doyle had said, thus for January, 1 month does not a quarter make. But we are down from the guidance that we have baked into the quarter.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then in terms of SG&A, George, and we're always looking to drive down our SG&A cost. And as we complete the merger with Plum Creek as we've already identified, there will be at least $100 million of hard dollar cost synergies. Most of that will be SG&
componenttext: And then in terms of SG&A, George, and we're always looking to drive down our SG&A cost. And as we complete the merger with Plum Creek as we've already identified, there will be at least $100 million of hard dollar cost synergies. Most of that will be SG&A related, and then of course, operational synergies on top of that. So it's like I said, we're never done on SG&A. The focus after the closer, the merger will quickly turn to the synergy -- hard dollar cost synergies that we outlined when we announced that merger.

componenttext: Well, as you said, we did close Forsyth. These were markets with limited growth potential and high costs. And we think as a result of that, we've laid out our OpEx target for 2016 and we're confident with these changes, Collin, that we will meet the specific target that we laid out for 2016 in terms of bottom-line EBITDA improvement of $15 million to $20 million in that business.

componenttext: Okay. Is there any way to think about how much of a drag maybe those facilities were in 2015 or they're not -- you don't really break it out that way?

componenttext: We don't really break it out that way, Collin. I'll just tell you, it does significantly improve our cost structure, it gets us focused on the markets and we need to be focused on and I think it's going to be a big benefit as we move into 2016.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Then moving to Timberlands. Just maybe as we enter the year here, just update us on your latest thinking as it relates to the potential improvement in sawlog prices in the U.S. outage here, what are you thinking about for 2016? And then just more br
componenttext: Okay. Then moving to Timberlands. Just maybe as we enter the year here, just update us on your latest thinking as it relates to the potential improvement in sawlog prices in the U.S. outage here, what are you thinking about for 2016? And then just more broadly, so as that time line continues to extend, how are you thinking about the price recovery in the South?

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so you think about southern log prices, Collin, our prices were up a couple of percent in 2015 versus '14, and we would anticipate a similar increase in '16 versus '15. From a broader picture, U.S. housing starts continue to improve, demand for lumber
componenttext: And so you think about southern log prices, Collin, our prices were up a couple of percent in 2015 versus '14, and we would anticipate a similar increase in '16 versus '15. From a broader picture, U.S. housing starts continue to improve, demand for lumber will rise and we expect detention in rising -- prices across the southern log markets. We are confident that, that's going to continue to pan out. And frankly, the additional mills, whether it be the Canadian coming down and investing in mills and increasing the productivity of those mills are a clause and are adding -- the 3 mills that they're adding, that's all positive from a demand standpoint for southern install logs as well. So we remain confident that we're going to reset inflection point and see southern sawlog prices begin to rise in a more aggressive basis than the 2% that we've seen over the last couple of years.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then switching gears and recognizing, there are some limitation, I reckon that's what you can as it relates to the disclosure. But I do want to touch on the financial projections in the proxy internally within Weyerhaeuser. I was curious if you
componenttext: Okay. And then switching gears and recognizing, there are some limitation, I reckon that's what you can as it relates to the disclosure. headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Patty, Doyle, first question is on the -- as you think about the analysis with the cellulose division, I understand that since most of it's legacy prop -- property bought 25 years ago, the basis is low. And I guess, the way you would need to help me think
componenttext: Patty, Doyle, first question is on the -- as you think about the analysis with the cellulose division, I understand that since most of it's legacy prop -- property bought 25 years ago, the basis is low. And I guess, the way you would need to help me think about this is obviously, if you do a spin, you would avoid some capital gain tax, I believe. But on the other hand, if you do this spin, there's a lot of costs I guess in terms of setting up a public company that you would not have to incur if you're just doing the direct sale of the assets. And I guess, could you give me some feel for the trade-off of that? Could you actually put a rough dollar value -- a cost of pursuing a spin versus just a sale?

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Chip, this is Patty. I think as we think about Cellulose Fibers strategic review, we're looking at all of those alternatives and evaluating them. I couldn't put any dollars on them at this point. You are correct in that the tax basis for Cellulose Fi
componenttext: Yes, Chip, this is Patty. I think as we think about Cellulose Fibers strategic review, we're looking at all of those alternatives and evaluating them. I couldn't put any dollars on them at this point. You are correct in that the tax basis for Cellulose Fibers is low. And so we would have on a cash sale, tax a gain, but we would have to compare that to what we would get in terms of a spend, both in terms of time as well as cost of setting up a separate company. But as we have done with all of our other strategic reviews over the course of time, we are looking at a broad range of options at this point.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. When you look at the Distribution business, I know that it's really nice to see how every business has hit their targets. Obviously, Doyle, the last couple of 3 years, except for that 1. And I didn't know if you wanted to sort of give us an update o
componenttext: Okay. When you look at the Distribution business, I know that it's really nice to see how every business has hit their targets. Obviously, Doyle, the last couple of 3 years, except for that 1. And I didn't know if you wanted to sort of give us an update on you're thinking in terms of how much more -- of time do they have before you might consider a strategic review of that business. And then maybe just more broadly, is your thinking toward all the Wood Products segment, all the manufacturing, has that change at all in light of the Plum Creek deal, in terms of, would this be an area that -- in other words, do you want to be a pure timber play? And maybe it's not as strategic.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016

componenttext: So Chip let me -- since its Super Bowl, we can -- let me use a football analogy on distribution.

componenttext: Yes, but you guys aren't in it.

componenttext: It's rough around as it is.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: A sidewalk, a frown on their face. But in terms of distribution, Chip, I would tell you, as I mentioned earlier, we have made improvements in that business. I think the business has earned the right to continue to be on the field at this point, but it's n
componenttext: A sidewalk, a frown on their face. But in terms of distribution, Chip, I would tell you, as I mentioned earlier, we have made improvements in that business. I think the business has earned the right to continue to be on the field at this point, but it's not earned a spot on the roster. So still, like I said earlier, still more to do, encouraged by the progress. Like I said, we made some significant changes in the fourth quarter of 2015, and we're confident that, that's going to help us accelerate progress and distribution going forward. So more work to do. In terms of Wood Products overall. Chip, as you heard us say and me say historically, we believe that this can be a very good business and create a lot of value for shareholders over a cycle, assuming that you run it effectively and get the cost structure to where it needs to be where you're back at the bottom and that you're fully capitalizing on the upturn in housing that we still have in front of us. We're encouraged by the progress we've made on the overall cost structure and our OpEx improvements, and still more to come. And like I said, very well positioned to continue to capitalize on the improvement and housing as we move forward.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two things. With the rating agencies have said that given the terms of the deal, they'd probably downgrade Weyerhaeuser. Since you said you want to remain acquisitive, would it make sense to scale back or slow down the buybacks to keep the agencies happy?
componenttext: Two things. With the rating agencies have said that given the terms of the deal, they'd probably downgrade Weyerhaeuser. Since you said you want to remain acquisitive, would it make sense to scale back or slow down the buybacks to keep the agencies happy? And the second question is may be a little more theoretical, West Rock has said publicly, it wants to get out of its land deals faster. Would that be something that might fit with your priorities? You've talked about wanting to expand but if cleaning up those lJVs something might be attractive to you?

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So let me talk about the acquisitive part and I'll turn it over to Patty to talk about the rating agency. Mark, we have said that we would like to grow the company and we said, that our primary opportunities were in Timberlands and thus, the Plum Creek tr
componenttext: So let me talk about the acquisitive part and I'll turn it over to Patty to talk about the rating agency. Mark, we have said that we would like to grow the company and we said, that our primary opportunities were in Timberlands and thus, the Plum Creek transaction. I would tell you in the near-term, our focus and maybe our singular focus is going to be on fully integrate thing Plum Creek and making sure we fully realize the synergy and the value of that transaction. So in the near term, that's going to be our primary focus and our plate's full on that, longer-term as we integrate that, and get the full benefits continuing to grow the company assuming we can find the right opportunity, it's something that we would consider. But right now, our focus is on Plum Creek and the integration there of.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Mark, as per your question about the rating agencies, S&P did write that based upon their understanding of what the leverage would look like after we close the transaction in order to repurchase the shares as we've talked about, that the leverage will
componenttext: And Mark, as per your question about the rating agencies, S&P did write that based upon their understanding of what the leverage would look like after we close the transaction in order to repurchase the shares as we've talked about, that the leverage will be certainly higher than where we have historically been. And so based upon their understanding at this point, they would expect that they would downgrade us from BBB to BBB-. So still investment-grade. We are focused on bringing that leverage down as we go forward. We are still committed to the $2.5 billion of share repurchase. But certainly, mindful that we'll need to bring the leverage down going forward. And we think that we'll have good opportunities to do that both with respect to the broader portfolio of 13 million acres of Timberland as well as depending upon the outcome of the strategic review of Cellulose Fibers.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're next question comes from the line of Mark Willoughby with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: You're next question comes from the line of Mark Willoughby with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: The whole Weyerhaeuser team has done an impressive job over the last couple of years. I had a few questions. One, Doyle, can you just clarify for us the review of cellulose especially, does that include things like the nor pack joint venture and that blea
componenttext: The whole Weyerhaeuser team has done an impressive job over the last couple of years. I had a few questions. One, Doyle, can you just clarify for us the review of cellulose especially, does that include things like the nor pack joint venture and that bleach board mill at Longview?

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, let me say thank you for those comments, Mark. And secondly, yes, the strategic review of Cellulose Fibers, includes all of the businesses in Cellulose Fibers.
componenttext: First, let me say thank you for those comments, Mark. And secondly, yes, the strategic review of Cellulose Fibers, includes all of the businesses in Cellulose Fibers.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then to kind of follow on, on Mark's question about the rating agencies. I mean there are some other things that you could look at divesting, like the business down in Uruguay, which is still not generating a lot of cash. Any thoughts on that, D
componenttext: Okay. And then to kind of follow on, on Mark's question about the rating agencies. I mean there are some other things that you could look at divesting, like the business down in Uruguay, which is still not generating a lot of cash. Any thoughts on that, Doyle?

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: As we've said, as part of the integration process, we'll do a thorough analysis of all 13 million plus million acres  with 13 plus million acres, and the fact, Mark, and I think this is an important one to highlight. With the recent tax extender package,
componenttext: As we've said, as part of the integration process, we'll do a thorough analysis of all 13 million plus million acres  with 13 plus million acres, and the fact, Mark, and I think this is an important one to highlight. With the recent tax extender package, reducing the built-in games period permanently to 5 years, we no longer have that constrains so 13 million acres plus no longer be under the built-in games tax, we have lots of flexibility in terms of what we can do going forward.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And the last question I had is to kind of come back to something called men's race. You got a lot of capital tied up in Southern Timberland, and you're going to commit a lot more capital here pretty to souther Timberlands. But if we look at the cash
componenttext: Okay. And the last question I had is to kind of come back to something called men's race. You got a lot of capital tied up in Southern Timberland, and you're going to commit a lot more capital here pretty to souther Timberlands. But if we look at the cash returns on Southern timber, they've been pretty anemic for about a decade now. What gives you the confidence that these returns are going to improve significantly over the next few years? And what do you think that trajectory looks like?

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mark, what gives me confidence and gives us confidence is basically supply and demand. And as you know, ultimately that works. And if you just look at it from a housing continuing to improve and housing has improved. It's been slow, but steady. So I
componenttext: Yes, Mark, what gives me confidence and gives us confidence is basically supply and demand. And as you know, ultimately that works. And if you just look at it from a housing continuing to improve and housing has improved. It's been slow, but steady. So I think that's going to be what's going to happen on the demand front. And the supply front, if housing continues to improve, the slides not going to come from the northwest. The slide is not going to come from Canada, and we see a little influx now because of the exchange rates in China. But ultimately, they, in Canada, are limited because of the time situation as to what they're going to be able to provide. So supply and demand works. We're going to reach at the inflection point and when we do, that's when we're going to see a significant change in Southern sawlog prices. So yes, it comes slower than any of us had hoped, but if you look at the basics of supply and demand, we remain confident that we will in fact, see improved prices in southern -- for southern sawlog, just like we have, historically.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Doyle, just to follow-up. We all I think buy into supply and demand, but on the supply-side, it seems like for many years here because of the weakness in housing, we've really been under harvesting the growth rate down in the South. So we've got some
componenttext: And Doyle, just to follow-up. We all I think buy into supply and demand, but on the supply-side, it seems like for many years here because of the weakness in housing, we've really been under harvesting the growth rate down in the South. So we've got some accumulated inventory and I just wonder how that accumulated inventory affects the rebound in pricing?

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mark, that's a really good point and there's no doubt that there is some accumulated inventory. Now as housing has improved over the last couple of years, we have started to work through some of that accumulated inventory, but there's still some out
componenttext: Yes, Mark, that's a really good point and there's no doubt that there is some accumulated inventory. Now as housing has improved over the last couple of years, we have started to work through some of that accumulated inventory, but there's still some out there. That's why I say, there's still a little bit of time if housing continues to improve to work through that accumulated inventory. But once we do that, you can get that inflection point of supply and demand, and that's where you start to see the significant increase in price.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016

componenttext: No. We can't give it to you by quarter, Mark. I can tell you that as you think about fourth quarter to first quarter, and the guidance that there's about roughly $10 million of additional maintenance expense in the first quarter compared to the fourth quarter.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe just as a follow on to, that $40 million to $50 million of OpEx improvement in Cellulose Fibers, does much or any of that come from being able to effectively reduce maintenance outage expenses? So will we see it in that variable year-over-year?
componenttext: Maybe just as a follow on to, that $40 million to $50 million of OpEx improvement in Cellulose Fibers, does much or any of that come from being able to effectively reduce maintenance outage expenses? So will we see it in that variable year-over-year?

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: That is not a key driver of the OpEx improvement that we laid out, Mark. There's of course, some benefit as we go to the 18 months schedule but that's not a big driver of the -- of what we saw in 2015 versus '14, nor what we will see in 2016 versus '15.
componenttext: That is not a key driver of the OpEx improvement that we laid out, Mark. There's of course, some benefit as we go to the 18 months schedule but that's not a big driver of the -- of what we saw in 2015 versus '14, nor what we will see in 2016 versus '15.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then maybe lastly, kind of following on Mark questions a little bit. One of the components of the bullish lumber as well as log stories, any expected reduction in supply coming from British Columbia related to [indiscernible] et cetera, doesn't seem t
componenttext: And then maybe lastly, kind of following on Mark questions a little bit. One of the components of the bullish lumber as well as log stories, any expected reduction in supply coming from British Columbia related to [indiscernible] et cetera, doesn't seem to have happened yet. And lots of reasons may be, but are you still of that view that we will see a reduction? And any color you can provide on how that might play into the market?

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mark. We are absolutely confident that, that's going to happen and all you have to do is spend some time in that area and see the devastation that the time beetle has in fact, cost you're also starting to see some announcements as you know, of some l
componenttext: Yes, Mark. We are absolutely confident that, that's going to happen and all you have to do is spend some time in that area and see the devastation that the time beetle has in fact, cost you're also starting to see some announcements as you know, of some lumber mill closures because of that. I think what's happened is part of that has just been distorted by the fact that there's been less demand from China. So some of the impact from what would -- normally lumber, that would normally get from China is going to come to the U.S. and that has temporarily offset the time beetle situation. But if you just look at what the allowable costs are, if you look at just the overall fiber situation in Canada, we are confident that the time beetle scenario is going to play out.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we have time for one more question your final question comes the line of Paul Quinn with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: And we have time for one more question your final question comes the line of Paul Quinn with RBC Capital Markets.

componenttext: Just looking at your overall volumes in both timber well, I guess, timber, lumber and OSB, what are you planning for 2016? I notice 2015 volumes were down but you had gains in lumber and OSB, just wondering at a higher level what the plan is.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we would tell you that for 2016 in terms of sawlog's overall, we would see an interest volume to be flat may be down just very slightly. In terms of lumber and OSB, part of that of course, will be dependent on markets. But as we continue to improv
componenttext: Yes. So we would tell you that for 2016 in terms of sawlog's overall, we would see an interest volume to be flat may be down just very slightly. In terms of lumber and OSB, part of that of course, will be dependent on markets. But as we continue to improve our reliability, we would think lumber and OSB volumes would be up slightly in '16 versus '15.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just a follow-up, just flat to down on the log side, is that related to not so robust markets? Or is that because you're logging it at this sustainable level?
componenttext: Okay. And just a follow-up, just flat to down on the log side, is that related to not so robust markets? Or is that because you're logging it at this sustainable level?

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think it's more related to the fact that we're logging it at sustainable levels. As we've said, we have the ability in any given year to flex 5% or maybe a little more depending on markets. So we'll see how that plays out and that will ultimately, d
componenttext: No. I think it's more related to the fact that we're logging it at sustainable levels. As we've said, we have the ability in any given year to flex 5% or maybe a little more depending on markets. So we'll see how that plays out and that will ultimately, determine what the harvest levels are. But basically, we are harvesting at sustainable levels.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016

componenttext: Thank you, I would like to turn the call back over to Doyle, for any closing remarks.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and thank you for everybody's interest today. Before -- or in closing today, I want to say some words about Patty, as this will be her last earnings call on behalf of Weyerhaeuser as she will retire later this year. Specifically, I want to ackn
componenttext:
Thank you, and thank you for everybody's interest today. Before -- or in closing today, I want to say some words about Patty, as this will be her last earnings call on behalf of Weyerhaeuser as she will retire later this year. Specifically, I want to acknowledge her amazing work as a CFO since 2007 and personally thank her for partnering with me over the last couple of years as we've taken significant steps to make Weyerhaeuser truly a great company. 
Thank you, Patty for all you've done for Weyerhaeuser.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Doyle, let me just -- before you close the call, interject one additional thank you to the analyst community on the call. We are very fortunate as a company to have a whole host of very knowledgeable people and I've enjoyed the dialogue over the yea
componenttext: Well, Doyle, let me just -- before you close the call, interject one additional thank you to the analyst community on the call. We are very fortunate as a company to have a whole host of very knowledgeable people and I've enjoyed the dialogue over the years. And as I do retire from Weyerhaeuser now, I feel very confident in the management team going forward. I'm really pleased with the progress that we've made on portfolio performance and capital allocation, and couldn't be more pleased with my successor, once we close this transaction, Russell Hagan. I think that as we go forward, since I will continue to be a significant shareholder, I think that we have a lot of additional capabilities and levers to pull to create ongoing value for shareholders. So Doyle, thanks to you and thanks to the while senior management team and employees of Weyerhaeuser.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Patty. And thanks, everyone, for joining us this morning, and thank you for your interest in Weyerhaeuser.
componenttext: Thank you, Patty. And thanks, everyone, for joining us this morning, and thank you for your interest in Weyerhaeuser.
