componenttext: Just wanted to follow-up on the Real Estate and the stepping up of activity there later this year and into next year. Is that primarily going to be on legacy Weyerhaeuser lands? Or would we -- should we expect it to be kind of a mix of legacy Weyerhaeuser and Plum Creek? Because obviously, the Plum Creek lands presumably were stepped up, but the Weyerhaeuser lands haven't been.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Mark, this is Russell. We'll see a mix. But we may see some more Plum Creek lands coming in, in that third and fourth quarter, which will result in a little higher basis because of that step up. As we look at the combined portfolio, obviously, we're fo
componenttext: So Mark, this is Russell. We'll see a mix. But we may see some more Plum Creek lands coming in, in that third and fourth quarter, which will result in a little higher basis because of that step up. As we look at the combined portfolio, obviously, we're focused on getting to the Weyerhaeuser lands through the AVO process, but in conjunction with that, we're looking at all the opportunities on a combined portfolio and it really does provide us with a lot of optionality as far as which lands to bring to market.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, shifting gears a little bit. But any kind of big picture thoughts on how you'll be going about the dividend, recognizing you've had a lot of improvement in your Wood Products business, it's kind of underlying earnings there. Yet Timbers ma
componenttext: Okay. And then, shifting gears a little bit. But any kind of big picture thoughts on how you'll be going about the dividend, recognizing you've had a lot of improvement in your Wood Products business, it's kind of underlying earnings there. Yet Timbers maybe been a little bit slow to see the price improvement in the South. How -- what might be kind of a helpful way of thinking through how you'd be approaching the dividend at this point? And if it's changed at all as your mix of businesses have changed quite a bit in the last year or so?

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, as you know, we're committed to a growing and sustainable dividend. 2016 is going to be very noisy. As we continue to move forward, there are lots of moving pieces. As we look into 2017, we're going to continue to benefit from cost and operational s
componenttext: Mark, as you know, we're committed to a growing and sustainable dividend. 2016 is going to be very noisy. As we continue to move forward, there are lots of moving pieces. As we look into 2017, we're going to continue to benefit from cost and operational synergies, continued OpEx improvement and strong housing markets, all those types of things. We will be spending time with our board as we move forward to figure out exactly how to think about the dividend on a go-forward basis with the mix of assets that we now have, with the much more stable earnings stream that comes from Timberland, and then the improvements that we've made in our Wood Products to take some of the volatility out of that and most importantly, probably, to eliminate some of the downside in our Wood Products operation on a go-forward basis. So all things that we'll be factoring in to what the appropriate level of our dividend is on a go-forward basis.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And one last one, if I could. The tax rate guidance, 18% to 20%, I guess a little higher than I would have anticipated. And maybe, one question would be does the interest expense -- can that get allocated to taxable -- the taxable REIT subsidiary? Or does some of that actually run through the -- not get that benefit?

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Mark, we're guiding to 18% to 20% for our full year tax rate. As far as the allocation of the interest expense between the taxable REIT subsidiary and the REIT, we actually have debt that is associated with taxable REIT subsidiaries. So that's all
componenttext: Yes. So Mark, we're guiding to 18% to 20% for our full year tax rate. As far as the allocation of the interest expense between the taxable REIT subsidiary and the REIT, we actually have debt that is associated with taxable REIT subsidiaries. So that's allocated and tax affected accordingly, and then there's debt associated with the REIT asset so you'll get a blended rate.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Ginger and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome, everyone to the Weyerhaeuser Company's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions]I will now turn the call ove
componenttext:
Good morning. My name is Ginger and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome, everyone to the Weyerhaeuser Company's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions]
I will now turn the call over to our host, Beth Baum. Ma'am please go ahead.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ginger. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today to discuss Weyerhaeuser's second quarter 2016 earnings. This call is being webcast at www.weyerhaeuser.com. Our earnings release and presentation materials can also be found on
componenttext:
Thank you, Ginger. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today to discuss Weyerhaeuser's second quarter 2016 earnings. This call is being webcast at www.weyerhaeuser.com. Our earnings release and presentation materials can also be found on our website. 
Please review the warning statements in our press release and on the presentation slides concerning the risks associated with forward-looking statements as forward-looking statements will be made during this conference call. We will discuss non-GAAP financial measures, and a reconciliation of GAAP can be found in the earnings materials on our website.
On the call this morning are Doyle Simons, Chief Executive Officer; and Russell Hagen, Chief Financial Officer.
I will now turn the call over to Doyle Simons.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Beth and Welcome, everyone. This morning, Weyerhaeuser reported second quarter net earnings of $157 million or $0.21 per diluted share on net sales from continuing operations of $1.7 billion. Second quarter results include after-tax earnings of
componenttext:
Thank you, Beth and Welcome, everyone. This morning, Weyerhaeuser reported second quarter net earnings of $157 million or $0.21 per diluted share on net sales from continuing operations of $1.7 billion. Second quarter results include after-tax earnings of $38 million from discontinued operations and $11 million of after-tax charges for merger and legal expenses. Results for our entire Cellulose Fibers segment are reported as discontinued operations. Excluding discontinued operations and special items, we earned $130 million or $0.17 per diluted share. 
Second quarter adjusted EBITDA from our continuing operations was $413 million, and this represents an improvement of $77 million or 23% compared with first quarter results. I'm proud of our second quarter operating performance. Our teams continued to execute well and delivered solid operating results, including Wood Products' strongest second quarter in over a decade. In the quarter, we also announced the sale of our pulp mill and liquid packaging board facility for collective proceeds of $2.5 billion or approximately $1.8 billion after-tax; closed the Twin Creeks transactions, receiving $440 million in cash and a transaction valuing 260,000 acres of Southern Timberlands at $2,150 per-acre. 
We purchased over $830 million worth of our common shares and made strong progress on merger integration activities as we work together to successfully integrate Plum Creek and fully capture the cost and operational synergies that will drive superior value for our shareholders.
Before I turn to our second quarter business results, let me make some brief comments about the housing market. Single-family housing starts continued to grow at double-digit rate and year-to-date activity remains in line with our expectations. Through June, single-family starts had improved 15% compared with 2015 on a seasonally adjusted basis and total U.S. starts were up 8%. 
Although supply side constraints such as skilled labor, permitting delays and fees, and rising manning [ph] construction costs dampened the market's acceleration during the second quarter, solid economic fundamentals, including job growth and historically low mortgage rates continue to drive improving housing demand. We continue to anticipate approximately 1.2 million housing starts for 2016, in line with consensus estimates. 
Let me now turn to our business segments. I will begin the discussion with Timberlands, Charts 3 to 5. Timberlands contributed $125 million to second quarter earnings. Adjusted EBITDA for Timberlands increased by $21 million to $220 million. Noncash depletion and amortization costs increased by $25 million following a full quarter of higher depletion rates resulting from acquisition accounting. 
Western Timberlands contributed $114 million to second quarter EBITDA compared with $118 million in the first quarter. Western Sea harbor's volumes increased, but average realizations for Western logs declined modestly, primarily due to a greater proportion of sales to domestic and Chinese markets. As anticipated, sales volumes to Japan declined in the second quarter as first quarter pulled forward demand in advance of its scheduled consumption tax increase, which was later delayed. Pricing for our Japanese logs moderated slightly in the quarter. Volumes to China rose due to seasonally higher construction activity and average log realizations were essentially flat. Log inventories at Chinese ports were little changed in the quarter and remain at normalized levels. 
In Western domestic markets, log supply and demand remained balanced during the quarter. Average realizations declined slightly due to mix and per unit logging costs increased seasonally as second quarter harvest includes a greater proportion of higher elevation white wood. 
Southern Timberlands contributed $99 million to second quarter EBITDA, $22 million more than the first quarter. Southern fee harvest volumes increased by 40% due to a full quarter of Plum Creek operations. Realizations for southern logs declined slightly due to mix as second quarter sales included a higher percentage of pulp wood. Silviculture and forestry cost increased due to catch up on first quarter activity that has been delayed due to wet weather. 
Northern Timberlands EBITDA improved slightly compared to the first quarter. 
The Timberlands business remains relentlessly focused on capturing operational excellence and is on track to achieve its $30 million to $50 million operational excellence targets for 2016. During the quarter, internal benchmarking teams completed an initial survey of operational synergy opportunities and prioritized areas with the greatest potential value. A deep-dive comparison of each company's practices and their highest value areas is underway. We are pleased with the progress to date and look forward to capturing these opportunities later this year and into 2017. 
Real Estate, Energy and Natural Resources, Charts 6 and 7. Real Estate and ENR contributed $12 million to second quarter earnings compared with $15 million in the first quarter. EBITDA for the second quarter totaled $28 million. For Real Estate, the number of acres sold declined slightly due to the timing of transaction closings. Average price per acre increased as second quarter included the sale of a high-value parcel in Cannon Beach, Oregon. 
EBITDA from Energy and Natural Resources operations improved slightly. 
Our Real Estate team is running full all out as they apply Plum Creek's asset value optimization or ABO process to the legacy Weyerhaeuser Timberlands. This work is proceeding well and we continue to anticipate the process will be substantially complete in early 2017. We expect Real Estate activity will ramp up significantly in the fourth quarter of this year and into 2017, as this process moves toward conclusion. 
Wood Products, Charts 8 and 9. Wood Products contributed $156 million to second quarter earnings, an improvement of 80% compared with first quarter. By effectively capitalizing on improving markets and ongoing operational excellence initiatives, the business delivered its strongest second quarter since 2005. 
Adjusted EBITDA increased to $189 million, $72 million more than the first quarter. EBITDA from lumber rose to $96 million. This is an improvement of $45 million or nearly 90% compared with the first quarter. Average realizations improved nearly 10% and sales volume increased by 8%. 
The business also had another strong quarter operationally. Western log costs declined and recovery improved and manufacturing cost net of logs decreased due to the continued benefit of operational excellence initiatives. 
OSB contributed $43 million to EBITDA, $12 million more than the first quarter. Average sales realizations increased 12% and our mills continued to run well. 
Engineered Wood Products' EBITDA increased to $45 million, $14 million more than the first quarter. Sales volume rose due to seasonally higher demand and a full quarter of Plum Creek, MDS and plywood operations. Average realizations for solid section and I-Joist declined slightly due to mix. 
In distribution, EBITDA rose $5 million compared with first quarter due to improved sales volume, higher margins and ongoing cost control. The business has increased EBITDA by $14 million year-to-date against their 2016 full year target of $15 million to $20 million. 
Later in the quarter, we announced changes to improve the profitability of our Montana Wood Product operations. In the third quarter, we will permanently close the lumber and plywood mill in Columbia Falls. These moves will allow us to align the available log supply with our manufacturing capacity, including adding shifts at our Kalispell facilities and best position our Montana operations for long-term success. 
Wood Products remains relentlessly focused on OpEx initiatives and is on track to achieve its 2016 target. During our first quarter earnings call, we indicated we thought second quarter Wood Products' results could be comparable to second quarter 2013, a time when we were just beginning our OpEx journey and lumber and OSB pricing was significantly higher than it is today. In fact, we exceeded second quarter 2013 EBITDA by $23 million despite the fact that average lumber realizations in the second quarter were $35 per thousand lower than 3 years ago and average realizations for OSB were more than $90 per thousand lower than they were in second quarter 2013. This overall improvement highlights the significant contribution operational excellence is making to our business results. 
I will now turn to our -- to discontinued operations, Chart 11. As I previously mentioned [indiscernible] our entire Cellulose Fiber segment is being reported as discontinued operations. This includes results from our pulp mill, a liquid packaging board facility and a printing papers joint venture. Discontinued operations contributed $52 million to pretax earnings compared with $29 million in the first quarter. Average sales realizations for pulp and liquid packaging rose compared with first quarter and sales volumes for liquid packaging increased. Maintenance and energy costs declined slightly. 
Second quarter results also reflect accounting changes resulting from the reclassification as discontinued operations. Noncash depreciation expense decreased by $23 million compared with first quarter, due to a requirement to seek depreciation on assets held for sale. And corporate overhead expense previously allocated to cellulose fiber is now reported in unallocated items. This change affects both current and prior periods. These expenses total approximately $9 million per quarter or approximately $35 million on an annual basis. The effect of these accounting changes was largely offset by charges associated with the strategic review process and other transaction expenses. 
Yesterday, we received Hart-Scott-Rodino clearance in the U.S. for the announced sale of our pulp mills to International Paper. We continue to make progress through remaining regulatory approvals, primarily competition clearance and several foreign jurisdictions. We anticipate closing the transaction in the fourth quarter. 
Similarly, we have received Hart-Scott-Rodino clearance for the sale of our liquid packaging business and continue to progress with remaining approvals. We expect to close the liquid packaging transaction in the third quarter.
The process for our printing papers joint venture is proceeding well. We are actively working with prospective buyers and we will update you when that review is complete. 
I want to thank our Cellulose Fibers employees for maintaining their focus on operating safely and delivering strong results throughout the strategic review and sale processes. 
I will now turn it over to Russell to discuss some financial items and our third quarter outlook.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Doyle, and good morning. The outlook for the third quarter is presented in slide -- Chart 14 of the earnings slides. For Timberlands, we expect third quarter adjusted EBITDA will decline slightly or roughly 5% compared to the second quarter due
componenttext:
Thank you, Doyle, and good morning. The outlook for the third quarter is presented in slide -- Chart 14 of the earnings slides. For Timberlands, we expect third quarter adjusted EBITDA will decline slightly or roughly 5% compared to the second quarter due to seasonality and lower export prices. In our Western Timberland operations, overall, we expect harvest volumes to be similar to second quarter levels. Although Japanese housing activity remains strong, we anticipate prices will soften as markets adjust to the delayed increase in the consumption tax. In China, seasonally slower construction activity and continued currency headwinds will result in lower sales volumes and moderately lower pricing. 
Domestic log volumes and prices are expected to remain stable. Operating conditions throughout the Western region have been favorable as the risk of fire has been low. Western logging costs will be seasonally higher in the third quarter as summer weather allows us to ship harvest activities to higher elevations, which have a higher percentage of cable logging and longer haul distances. In the South, fee harvest volumes are expected to be slightly higher than the second quarter, but on a lower grade mix as third quarter activity typically includes a higher percentage of sitting volume. Silviculture and growth spending will also be seasonally higher. 
In the North, third quarter harvest volumes will be significantly higher than the prior quarter. Note that second quarter harvests are the lowest of the year because of logging and hauling limitations due to spring breakup or as they like to say in the northern woods, the mud season. We expect average sales realizations will be similar to second quarter levels. 
In Real Estate and Energy and Natural Resources segment, we expect significantly higher earnings and adjusted EBITDA from Real Estate sales during the second half of the year; nearly all this improvement will occur in the fourth quarter.
Third quarter Real Estate activity will be primarily focused on continuing work on the AVO process and building our inventory of higher and better use properties. We expect third quarter adjusted EBITDA will increase slightly compared to the second quarter, with the mix of Real Estate sales slightly heavier to higher basis lands. In the fourth quarter, we expect EBITDA will be more than double the third quarter level as the first results of AVO assessments in the portions of the U.S. South are taken to market and begin to move through to closing. 
For Wood Products, inventories throughout the supply chain remain tight as buyers continue to only purchase product to meet their immediate needs, which has been pushing lumber and OSB pricing higher as we enter the third quarter. We're anticipating comparable sales volumes and continued strength in lumber and OSB pricing in the third quarter as housing starts, especially single-family, continue to improve and builders move into the late summer building season. 
We expect to see continued solid performance in engineered Wood Products. Overall, we expect third quarter adjusted EBITDA and earnings for the Wood Products segment will be considerably higher than second quarter. Lumber and OSB prices improved throughout July. If prices stabilize at current levels for the balance of the quarter, the segment is on track to improve EBITDA and earnings by roughly 10% compared with second quarter. However, we believe there's continued upside for both lumber and OSB prices and anticipate earnings could exceed this level. 
Now let me direct your attention to Chart 10, which details the major components of our unallocated items. The contribution to earnings before special items was $1 million, $9 million lower than the first quarter results, which included a $13 million gain on foreign exchange. Note that unallocated corporate function expenses now include approximately $9 million of cost that were recorded in Cellulose Fibers segment prior to the discontinued operations reclassification. 
Chart 12 summarizes our key financial items. We ended the quarter with a cash balance of $485 million, up $74 million from the first quarter. Cash flow from operations, including Cellulose Fibers, was $492 million for the second quarter. This is an increase of $445 million over the first quarter, which is typically the lowest cash flow quarter of the year. In addition to increased cash flows from Wood Products and Timberland segments, we saw a positive variance in our working capital due to the seasonal decrease in inventory levels quarter-over-quarter. Cash from investing activities was a positive $350 million for the quarter as we received $440 million in cash proceeds from the Twin Creeks transaction, which closed on April 1. 
Capital expenditures for the second quarter totaled $101 million, including $12 million of our discontinued operations. We expect 2016 CapEx for our continuing operations will be approximately $425 million, with Timberlands' capital spending expected to total about $125 million for the year and Wood Products' spending of approximately $300 million. 
Financing cash flows included $831 million for share repurchases and $228 million for common dividends. As of June 30, we've drawn $1.4 billion of a $2.5 billion available under the term loan facilities. Long-term debt, not including the term loan balance of $1.4 billion, was $6.6 billion at the end of the second quarter. We intend to pay down the term loans with the proceeds from our recently announced asset sales. 
Interest expense of $114 million for the second quarter reflects a full quarter of interest for both the Plum Creek legacy debt and the new term loans. We expect interest expense will be comparable in the third quarter. 
For our continuing operations, the company anticipates the full year tax rate will be between 18% and 20% based on the expected mix of REIT and taxable REIT subsidiary income. 
I'll wrap up with Chart 13, which provides some additional detail on our share count and share repurchase activities. Through the end of the second quarter, we have repurchased 58 million shares of common stock under our February 2016 share repurchase program at an average price of $29.18 per share. 
We have continued our repurchase activity during the third quarter. And as of August 1, our cumulative repurchases totaled $1.98 billion or nearly 67 million shares at an average price of $29.45. The company did not repurchase shares during the period June 1 through June 28 because of the measurement period for our mandatory convertible preference shares. The mandatory convertible preference shares converted to common shares on July 1 at a rate of approximately 1.69 common shares per preference share. As a result, common shares outstanding increased by approximately 23.2 million shares subsequent to quarter end. 
Now I'll turn the call back to Doyle and look forward to your questions.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Russell. I will wrap up this morning with some brief comments on integration, synergies and SG&A. We continue to make strong progress on merger integration. I'm encouraged by the teamwork I see among employees at all levels as we work together
componenttext:
Thank you, Russell. I will wrap up this morning with some brief comments on integration, synergies and SG&A. We continue to make strong progress on merger integration. I'm encouraged by the teamwork I see among employees at all levels as we work together to service our customers, identify best practices and implement improved processes for our merged company. 
We have fully identified the sources of the $100 million of hard dollar cost synergies. As of the end of the second quarter, we are capturing about 1/3 of these reductions on a run-rate basis. I'm highly confident we will reach our $100 million run rate cost synergy target by the end of year one.
In addition to capturing merger synergies, we must address the $35 million of corporate costs formerly allocated to the Cellulose Fibers segment. To ensure our businesses remain competitive, we will eliminate these costs just as we did following the divestiture of our homebuilding business. We've been planning for the reduction as part of the strategic review process and anticipate eliminating these costs within 12 months after closing the International Paper transaction. 
In closing, I will mention that the move to our new Seattle headquarters remains on track for mid-September. 
I'm also pleased to announce that we will be holding an Investor Day in New York on Tuesday, December 13. We will send out the details and a press release later this morning. At that meeting, we will provide specific updates on progress against the key targets for our merged company and you will have the -- an opportunity to hear first-hand from each of our business leaders about their key initiatives as we work together to drive superior value for our shareholders. 
And now I'd like to open the floor for questions.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Anthony Pettinari from Citi.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Anthony Pettinari from Citi.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: In Timberlands, as you think about 3Q in the South, I think you talked about softer price/mix. If you take the impact of mix shifts away and you just look at same-product prices, I was wondering what you're seeing in July and August. Are prices just flat?
componenttext: In Timberlands, as you think about 3Q in the South, I think you talked about softer price/mix. If you take the impact of mix shifts away and you just look at same-product prices, I was wondering what you're seeing in July and August. Are prices just flat? Or are you seeing any kind of improvement in southern log prices?

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, Anthony, what we're seeing, and you're thinking about it exactly right on what I like to say, an apples-to-apples basis, prices, we anticipate will be essentially flat in the third quarter versus the second quarter.
componenttext: No, Anthony, what we're seeing, and you're thinking about it exactly right on what I like to say, an apples-to-apples basis, prices, we anticipate will be essentially flat in the third quarter versus the second quarter.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I guess what do you attribute that to? I mean, presumably lumber mills can pay more for fiber and housing starts are growing double-digits. Is there just too much inventory out there? Why aren't log prices improving or inflecting, as I think som
componenttext: Okay. And I guess what do you attribute that to? I mean, presumably lumber mills can pay more for fiber and housing starts are growing double-digits. Is there just too much inventory out there? Why aren't log prices improving or inflecting, as I think some of us thought that they might by now?

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Anthony, in the question -- and we've all talked about it is what is the inflection point where you see significant improvement in pricing? And we remain confident and housing continues to improve as you said as additional lumber capacity comes onlin
componenttext: Yes, Anthony, in the question -- and we've all talked about it is what is the inflection point where you see significant improvement in pricing? And we remain confident and housing continues to improve as you said as additional lumber capacity comes online. In the South, we remain confident we're going to hit that infection point based of our supply and demand reach equilibrium, and at that point, we believe we'll start to see Southern log prices begin to return to the levels they were prior to the recession. However, we don't think we're going to see that in the third quarter. We'll just have to wait as we move forward to hit that inflection point.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Okay. And then just in Wood Products. You mentioned the Columbia Falls announcement and adding shifts elsewhere. Was Columbia Falls -- will it end up being kind of net neutral from a capacity standpoint? And then just, generally, if you could talk a
componenttext: Okay. Okay. And then just in Wood Products. You mentioned the Columbia Falls announcement and adding shifts elsewhere. Was Columbia Falls -- will it end up being kind of net neutral from a capacity standpoint? And then just, generally, if you could talk about your Wood Products footprint. Are you adding capacity with the increase in starts? Or how should we think about that for the year?

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So for the year, Anthony, overall, we're running our facilities close to 95%, 96%, 97% operating rates due to these good markets. So you always have 1% or 2% of creep, but we don't anticipate adding any significant capacity in the near term. Columbia
componenttext: Yes. So for the year, Anthony, overall, we're running our facilities close to 95%, 96%, 97% operating rates due to these good markets. So you always have 1% or 2% of creep, but we don't anticipate adding any significant capacity in the near term. Columbia Falls, net-net, you will have lower capacity, but higher profitability. As we stated when we announced that, the reason for that move was to align the available fiber with the productive capacity. And by doing this, we are able to run the remaining mills full out with additional shifts, which will ensure the long-term success of our Montana operations and improve the overall profitability of our Montana operations on a go-forward basis.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from George Staphos from Bank of America.
componenttext: Your next question is from George Staphos from Bank of America.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Doyle, first question in wood. Obviously, very strong results; better than your guidance. As we look out the next couple of quarters, where do you see the most cost pressure? And you're doing a great job on SG&A relative to the revenue base in the busines
componenttext: Doyle, first question in wood. Obviously, very strong results; better than your guidance. As we look out the next couple of quarters, where do you see the most cost pressure? And you're doing a great job on SG&A relative to the revenue base in the business. That's obviously part of the program at Weyerhaeuser, but where do you start to see some tension here? How long can you hold the line there within wood? And then, I had a couple of follow-on questions on SG&A.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. In terms of cost pressures, George, at this point in time, we don't see any significant cost pressures now. If all runs up, you clearly would have some freight cost pressures and people continue to anticipate that happening at some point. But in the
componenttext: Yes. In terms of cost pressures, George, at this point in time, we don't see any significant cost pressures now. If all runs up, you clearly would have some freight cost pressures and people continue to anticipate that happening at some point. But in the near term, I don't see any significant cost pressures. We'd love to see some cost pressure from a log perspective, but we're not seeing that as we just referenced in the near term.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Yes, that was part of the question. The second question I wanted to get into is on engineered wood. It sounded like from your commentary that you're pleased with the performance there. And looking at the slide deck, if I saw it correctly, we've seen
componenttext: Okay. Yes, that was part of the question. The second question I wanted to get into is on engineered wood. It sounded like from your commentary that you're pleased with the performance there. And looking at the slide deck, if I saw it correctly, we've seen prices drifting a bit lower. If that's correct, what's driving that? Is it, again, lack of cost push? Is it, perhaps, some more competitive markets? Single-family starts are obviously doing well, which you would think would be beneficial for engineered wood, supply/demand and market trends. So how would you frame that for us?

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So what I would say on a pricing -- from a pricing perspective, a big part of the slight downward pressure we've seen is just having to do with mix. As we move forward, George, I would say that there are some price increases or a price increase that
componenttext: Yes. So what I would say on a pricing -- from a pricing perspective, a big part of the slight downward pressure we've seen is just having to do with mix. As we move forward, George, I would say that there are some price increases or a price increase that will be playing out in the West. But a portion of that price increase will be offset by some pricing pressure in the East as you have the dealer consolidation and all the different things that are happening from a customer perspective overall. But going forward, we would anticipate prices would be flat to maybe up slightly.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the last one. If, again, we did our math right, again you've done a very good job on SG&A over the last number of years across the businesses. If I look at Timberland, if I look at Real Estate and ENR, versus year-ago levels that ratio has
componenttext: Okay. And then the last one. If, again, we did our math right, again you've done a very good job on SG&A over the last number of years across the businesses. If I look at Timberland, if I look at Real Estate and ENR, versus year-ago levels that ratio has ticked up a bit. Obviously, some of that's probably just mix in Plum Creek. Again, can you help frame what the opportunity there is for cost reductions in the next couple of quarters as you come out of '16 and head into '17?

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, George. And the way we look at these cost reductions is pretty straightforward. We say what was the SG&A and R&D for both combined companies in 2015, and as we said, our goal and we're confident in reaching that goal, is by the first quarter of
componenttext: Thank you, George. And the way we look at these cost reductions is pretty straightforward. We say what was the SG&A and R&D for both combined companies in 2015, and as we said, our goal and we're confident in reaching that goal, is by the first quarter of 2017, we will be at that run rate. So we're -- as you would anticipate, George, we're on top of that. We know exactly where we are. We've identified the source of those synergies. And we're starting to realize some of it; more to come as we run through the balance of this year and into early next year. But that's the way we're monitoring it to make sure it does, to your point, in fact, show up on the bottom line.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016

componenttext: A few questions here. First, just maybe big picture. Talk a little bit more -- update us on how you think the softwood lumber negotiations are going to play out, and just kind of your update as far as bots if no deal is reached and the standstill period comes and goes without a deal.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. And as you know, we are very actively involved with and aligned with the position of the U.S. coalition and there's an ongoing dialogue between the coalition and our U.S. trade representatives. I do believe participants on both sides are interested
componenttext: Sure. And as you know, we are very actively involved with and aligned with the position of the U.S. coalition and there's an ongoing dialogue between the coalition and our U.S. trade representatives. I do believe participants on both sides are interested in a resolution. And I'm, frankly, encouraged that governments can -- that each of the governments are continuing to have discussions. As you know, this is a really important issue for Weyerhaeuser and we remain hopeful that an agreement can be reached prior to the deadline. But we're prepared to move forward if that doesn't happen in solid trade cases. So that's kind of where we are.

componenttext: Okay. I think -- one thing as far as in the prepared remarks, Russell, you talked about CapEx of $425 million. I think that's down from a comparable $450 million, I think, is what you guided to earlier. Is that right? And maybe what caused the change there?

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's correct. We did lower our CapEx spend. We brought it down a little bit on the timber side -- Timberlands side. As we look at the combined operations for Plum Creek and Weyerhaeuser, we've just refined that number as we move into the second hal
componenttext: Yes, that's correct. We did lower our CapEx spend. We brought it down a little bit on the timber side -- Timberlands side. As we look at the combined operations for Plum Creek and Weyerhaeuser, we've just refined that number as we move into the second half of the year.

Again, I know we talked on prior calls about the overall ramp showing up more in '17, but just from a modeling standpoint, how should we think about the fourth quarter?

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So Collin, as we look at the third quarter we expect the third quarter to be pretty similar to the second quarter. And then, again, as we bring more of the AVO properties into the market and we start ramping up that program, we would expect the four
componenttext: Sure. So Collin, as we look at the third quarter we expect the third quarter to be pretty similar to the second quarter. And then, again, as we bring more of the AVO properties into the market and we start ramping up that program, we would expect the fourth quarter to really increase, probably double the third quarter volume.

componenttext: Collin, I don't know that number exactly off the top of my head. We'll follow-up. But most of our revenue's generated out of the U.S. Although, Canada is an important part of our overall Wood Products operations. So I'll just have to get back -- we'll get back with you on that.

componenttext: Okay. And is there likely to be a difference between what you'll do, say, over the next 3 to 5 years in terms of harvest volumes and then what you might define as kind of long-term sustainable? Because I -- it seems to me both Longview and some of those need [indiscernible] properties offered opportunities for accelerated harvest in the near years.

componenttext: So Mark, what I would tell you, as you would anticipate, we're spending a lot of time updating our strategic harvest plan for the combined land base. So we'll see -- we'll give you some -- in the future, we'll give you some look at how we think that'll play out in the time horizon that you just laid out, but we're right in the middle of that process currently.

componenttextpreview: Okay. All right. And then, Doyle, can you just give us some sense of what you're expecting from Japan over the next couple of quarters?
componenttext: Okay. All right. And then, Doyle, can you just give us some sense of what you're expecting from Japan over the next couple of quarters?

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So Japan has been interesting in terms of how this consumption tax has played out in the second quarter. As we talked about, the volume was down due to the delay of the consumption tax and -- tax and prices decline. In the third quarter, Mark, our b
componenttext: Sure. So Japan has been interesting in terms of how this consumption tax has played out in the second quarter. As we talked about, the volume was down due to the delay of the consumption tax and -- tax and prices decline. In the third quarter, Mark, our best guess is that volumes will be kind of flat-ish and prices could be down slightly again until the consumption tax slate plays out; and also, some of the competition from the European laminators due to the strong dollar. And then as we look in our crystal ball, and our crystal ball isn't always right, but as we look in our crystal ball for the fourth quarter, we would expect some rebound in prices in both Japan and China. So that's kind of how we see it playing out.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. All right. And then, final question. Just when we think about the SLA, Doyle, is it -- would we be correct if we think that sort of the biggest issues for you guys and how this plays out is really the impact on sort of value of timber coming off of
componenttext: Okay. All right. And then, final question. Just when we think about the SLA, Doyle, is it -- would we be correct if we think that sort of the biggest issues for you guys and how this plays out is really the impact on sort of value of timber coming off of your Southern and your Western Timberlands?

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's no doubt, Mark, that that's an important component of getting the SLA right on a go-forward basis.
componenttext: There's no doubt, Mark, that that's an important component of getting the SLA right on a go-forward basis.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016

componenttext: But if we get tougher restraints, could we see you actually increase the amount of capital you put in the saw mills?

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mark, as you know, we have an ongoing -- a game plan to -- that we shared with you and others about the capital that we'll be spending in our Wood Products operation on a go-forward basis to make sure we're positioned well, to fully capitalize on the
componenttext: Yes, Mark, as you know, we have an ongoing -- a game plan to -- that we shared with you and others about the capital that we'll be spending in our Wood Products operation on a go-forward basis to make sure we're positioned well, to fully capitalize on the upturn and get our costs to where they need to be. So spending capital in our Wood Products operation at about the $300 million level that we've done over the past year or 2, we think is going to be the right level at least in the near term going forward.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016

componenttext: First question, a couple of just accounting things. One is, I know that when you sold the cellulose business, and congrats on getting that approval, they at least said that the EBITDA in '15 was $350 million. And I'm just wondering would that have really have been $386 million? Or does that $350 million not include that corporate cost number for them?

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Chip, I'm not -- that $350 million is really based on their calculations and based on their models. And so while we did see that number, you definitely want to look at what we're reporting up to the point of where it's going to be kind of out of our syste
componenttext: Chip, I'm not -- that $350 million is really based on their calculations and based on their models. And so while we did see that number, you definitely want to look at what we're reporting up to the point of where it's going to be kind of out of our system. So I really can't comment on how they came up with that particular number.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Were they -- so that's what it was for '15. But I guess, another way to ask the question is, if I look at like last year's EBITDA, as you reported it for the segment, then obviously, about $36 million of the EBITDA would have been $36 million higher witho
componenttext: Were they -- so that's what it was for '15. But I guess, another way to ask the question is, if I look at like last year's EBITDA, as you reported it for the segment, then obviously, about $36 million of the EBITDA would have been $36 million higher without these corporate cost allocations. Is that fair?

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's correct.
componenttext: Yes, that's correct.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then second question is I know -- I believe this is typically the case. But when you make it a discontinued operations, I believe the number you present in your slide includes all the cash costs, but not depreciation. Did you -- in other words,
componenttext: Okay. And then second question is I know -- I believe this is typically the case. But when you make it a discontinued operations, I believe the number you present in your slide includes all the cash costs, but not depreciation. Did you -- in other words, you said that it made $52 million, but that, I would assume, does not include depreciation? Or does that bear any depreciation? Or for that matter, any interest expense?

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we -- there's $23 million of depreciation associated with that. That was -- we did -- we stopped mid-quarter. If you looked at prior quarters, it would be about -- the equivalent would be about $38 million of depreciation.
componenttext: Yes, so we -- there's $23 million of depreciation associated with that. That was -- we did -- we stopped mid-quarter. If you looked at prior quarters, it would be about -- the equivalent would be about $38 million of depreciation.

componenttext: Okay. So you actually had $38 million per quarter going into the second quarter, but then you did $23 million in the second and it will be 0 in the third. Is that fair?

componenttext: Correct.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's very helpful. And then just a more broader question, thanks for those details, is when you look at Eastern Canada, I've been hearing that -- and I don't know -- I don't think you guys are terribly active there, but as you think about the lumb
componenttext: Okay. That's very helpful. And then just a more broader question, thanks for those details, is when you look at Eastern Canada, I've been hearing that -- and I don't know -- I don't think you guys are terribly active there, but as you think about the lumber market. It seems like Eastern Canada, I'm hearing that their harvest or their growth of timber has actually come back in recent years. And that there would be more activity there in lumber and perhaps even plywood, but lumber in particular if there was any market for off-take, OSB plants or pulp mills. And do you agree with that? In other words, do you think that you could see potential supply, leaving aside any kind of trade issues, coming from Eastern Canada? Or do you think that's not likely?

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Chip, I would say, at least from our standpoint, it's in the not likely category. We have not seen what you're referencing and don't think additional capacity or additional capability is going to be available in Eastern Canada.
componenttext: Yes. Chip, I would say, at least from our standpoint, it's in the not likely category. We have not seen what you're referencing and don't think additional capacity or additional capability is going to be available in Eastern Canada.

componenttext: Doyle, is it safe to say that with the better lumber prices and very successful asset sales that you're feeling pretty good that Weyerhaeuser has addressed the rating agencies issues, and that, at this point, you've got room to execute on your buybacks the way you want to, rather than to make them happy?

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016

componenttext: Yes, Mark. This is Russell. We definitely spend time with the rating agencies to make sure that they understand our deposition and our EBITDA generation. And we're very comfortable with where we're at with the rating agencies in our current investment-grade rating.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And, Mark, you referenced the share repurchase and we have -- as we said, we're going to do it on an accelerated basis. We've essentially completed the $2 billion in, I guess, less than 6 months, and did it at what we think is an attractive value from a s
componenttext: And, Mark, you referenced the share repurchase and we have -- as we said, we're going to do it on an accelerated basis. We've essentially completed the $2 billion in, I guess, less than 6 months, and did it at what we think is an attractive value from a shareholder perspective of less than $29.50 per share. So pleased with the progress that we've made on the share repurchase.

componenttext: That's super. And just one quick comment or question on the log realizations. We've heard that smaller landowners in the South have been more aggressive. Do you think that's one of the reasons why we haven't seen log prices keeping up? Or is that not as widespread as we're hearing?

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think that is a component of what's happened on the log pricing. Small landowners, you never know exactly what motivates them or when they bring things to market, but clearly, they're -- we have seen some of that happening over the past year or 2.
componenttext: No, I think that is a component of what's happened on the log pricing. Small landowners, you never know exactly what motivates them or when they bring things to market, but clearly, they're -- we have seen some of that happening over the past year or 2.

componenttextpreview: A quick follow-up on the buybacks. If I remember correctly, it was initially going to be $2 billion of the $2.5 billion was going to be accelerated, and I'm just wondering if you could give some perspective on your approach to that remaining $500 million.
componenttext: A quick follow-up on the buybacks. If I remember correctly, it was initially going to be $2 billion of the $2.5 billion was going to be accelerated, and I'm just wondering if you could give some perspective on your approach to that remaining $500 million. Will that be also accelerated or marked for more opportunistic?

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So you're exactly right, Gail. What we said is that the authorization for $2.5 billion, that we would do $2 billion on an accelerated basis. And as I just mentioned, we've essentially completed that. We've also said consistently that once we do that,
componenttext: Yes. So you're exactly right, Gail. What we said is that the authorization for $2.5 billion, that we would do $2 billion on an accelerated basis. And as I just mentioned, we've essentially completed that. We've also said consistently that once we do that, we'll take a pause and then we'll work closer with our board to determine the timing of the additional $500 million. So that's what we'll be doing.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. This might be a little bit off-the-wall, but Plum Creek used to talk about trying to build an export market out of the South. And is that something -- an effort that you're continuing and kind of what your view would be from a -- on the long-term?
componenttext: Okay. This might be a little bit off-the-wall, but Plum Creek used to talk about trying to build an export market out of the South. And is that something -- an effort that you're continuing and kind of what your view would be from a -- on the long-term?

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. We are, as you would anticipate, constantly evaluating markets and the way to grow markets. As you also know, the South is very small in terms of export market currently, but we'll continue to look at opportunities as we move forward and we think th
componenttext: Sure. We are, as you would anticipate, constantly evaluating markets and the way to grow markets. As you also know, the South is very small in terms of export market currently, but we'll continue to look at opportunities as we move forward and we think that market will, in fact, develop over time.

componenttext: Yes. So those are the joint venture partnerships that Plum Creek entered into. Given that's a joint venture and we treat that with -- as equity accounting, we'll see the benefit of that as they execute on that plan.

componenttext: Just wanted to follow-up on the Real Estate and the stepping up of activity there later this year and into next year. Is that primarily going to be on legacy Weyerhaeuser lands? Or would we -- should we expect it to be kind of a mix of legacy Weyerhaeuser and Plum Creek? Because obviously, the Plum Creek lands presumably were stepped up, but the Weyerhaeuser lands haven't been.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Mark, this is Russell. We'll see a mix. But we may see some more Plum Creek lands coming in, in that third and fourth quarter, which will result in a little higher basis because of that step up. As we look at the combined portfolio, obviously, we're fo
componenttext: So Mark, this is Russell. We'll see a mix. But we may see some more Plum Creek lands coming in, in that third and fourth quarter, which will result in a little higher basis because of that step up. As we look at the combined portfolio, obviously, we're focused on getting to the Weyerhaeuser lands through the AVO process, but in conjunction with that, we're looking at all the opportunities on a combined portfolio and it really does provide us with a lot of optionality as far as which lands to bring to market.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, shifting gears a little bit. But any kind of big picture thoughts on how you'll be going about the dividend, recognizing you've had a lot of improvement in your Wood Products business, it's kind of underlying earnings there. Yet Timbers ma
componenttext: Okay. And then, shifting gears a little bit. But any kind of big picture thoughts on how you'll be going about the dividend, recognizing you've had a lot of improvement in your Wood Products business, it's kind of underlying earnings there. Yet Timbers maybe been a little bit slow to see the price improvement in the South. How -- what might be kind of a helpful way of thinking through how you'd be approaching the dividend at this point? And if it's changed at all as your mix of businesses have changed quite a bit in the last year or so?

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, as you know, we're committed to a growing and sustainable dividend. 2016 is going to be very noisy. As we continue to move forward, there are lots of moving pieces. As we look into 2017, we're going to continue to benefit from cost and operational s
componenttext: Mark, as you know, we're committed to a growing and sustainable dividend. 2016 is going to be very noisy. As we continue to move forward, there are lots of moving pieces. As we look into 2017, we're going to continue to benefit from cost and operational synergies, continued OpEx improvement and strong housing markets, all those types of things. We will be spending time with our board as we move forward to figure out exactly how to think about the dividend on a go-forward basis with the mix of assets that we now have, with the much more stable earnings stream that comes from Timberland, and then the improvements that we've made in our Wood Products to take some of the volatility out of that and most importantly, probably, to eliminate some of the downside in our Wood Products operation on a go-forward basis. So all things that we'll be factoring in to what the appropriate level of our dividend is on a go-forward basis.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And one last one, if I could. The tax rate guidance, 18% to 20%, I guess a little higher than I would have anticipated. And maybe, one question would be does the interest expense -- can that get allocated to taxable -- the taxable REIT subsidiary? O
componenttext: Okay. And one last one, if I could. The tax rate guidance, 18% to 20%, I guess a little higher than I would have anticipated. And maybe, one question would be does the interest expense -- can that get allocated to taxable -- the taxable REIT subsidiary? Or does some of that actually run through the -- not get that benefit?

headline: Weyerhaeuser Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Mark, we're guiding to 18% to 20% for our full year tax rate. As far as the allocation of the interest expense between the taxable REIT subsidiary and the REIT, we actually have debt that is associated with taxable REIT subsidiaries. So that's all
componenttext: Yes. So Mark, we're guiding to 18% to 20% for our full year tax rate. As far as the allocation of the interest expense between the taxable REIT subsidiary and the REIT, we actually have debt that is associated with taxable REIT subsidiaries. So that's allocated and tax affected accordingly, and then there's debt associated with the REIT asset so you'll get a blended rate.
